lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: Dietl’s Swipe at Judge and Mayor’s Wife May Cloud His G.O.P. Mayoral Bid
abstract: Bo Dietl, who hopes to run for mayor as a Republican, defended himself against accusations of racism after saying he knew he “had a problem” with a black judge in a court case.
lead_paragraph: For one night, for two hours at least, Republicans appeared giddy over their prospects in the New York City mayoral race.

headline: The G.O.P. Health Bill Is Alive Again. Here’s a Quick Way to Catch Up.
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A look at what the health bill would do, who it would affect, and how it changed to get more lawmakers to yes.
lead_paragraph: The Republican plan to repeal Obamacare and replace it with something quite different is heading for a House vote Thursday, after an embarrassing false start in March. The bill, the American Health Care Act, has changed considerably since it was first introduced. Here’s a refresher course to our coverage of what’s inside it. Click the links for fuller stories on each subject.

headline: ‘Wonder Woman,’ ‘Spider-Man’ and How Trailers Push the Familiar
abstract: A look at efforts to make superheroes we’ve seen before stand out at crowded multiplexes.
lead_paragraph: The summer blockbuster movie season kicks off when “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2” hits multiplexes across America on Friday, May 5 — and it’s a good time to take a look at the rest of the year’s slate of big-screen superhero adventures.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Analysis of Every Pick in Round 1
abstract: The Browns took defensive end Myles Garrett with the top overall pick. Here’s a look at how each team fared in the first round.
lead_paragraph: The first round of the 2017 N.F.L. draft featured several trades and a few surprising selections. The Cleveland Browns ended up with three first-round picks, and the Chicago Bears surprised most observers by trading up to the No. 2 spot to draft a quarterback, even though they paid a lot of money for one in the off-season. Here is a look at each player selected in the first round:

headline: Review: Rami Malek as a Drifter With a Past in ‘Buster’s Mal Heart’
abstract: Mr. Malek, of “Mr. Robot,” heads for the hills of Montana as a man fleeing a soul-deadening job and the burdens of modern life.
lead_paragraph: In the oddly named “Buster’s Mal Heart,” an unkempt vagrant (Rami Malek) wanders the hills of Montana, squatting in empty vacation homes and sometimes defecating in the cookware. Long known to the authorities as Buster, he calls in to radio shows to rant about a coming apocalypse.

headline: Review: Lovingly Tending the Livestock in ‘Boone’
abstract: A documentary observes life — births, milking and vegetable picking — on a goat farm in Oregon.
lead_paragraph: Anyone used to the convenience of city living should feel a tad guilty expressing impatience with “Boone,” a loving portrait of a goat dairy farm in Jacksonville, Ore., from the photojournalist Christopher LaMarca. If you buy milk of any kind, it’s only fair to see what happens before it reaches the store.

headline: Becky Suss’s Painted Memories Have a Solo Show in Chelsea
abstract: The artist’s large-scale portrayals of domestic interiors are at the Jack Shainman Gallery at West 20th Street.
lead_paragraph: When her grandparents’ Long Island home was sold and demolished, the artist Becky Suss ended up with much of its contents in her Philadelphia studio: sculptures, paintings, pillows, vases. So she started painting rooms filled with them.

headline: An Artist Who Talks Fast but Makes Meditative Films
abstract: Korakrit Arunanondchai’s multimedia work includes a man-sized rat suit, a grandmother’s possessions and thoughts on extinction.
lead_paragraph: The artist Korakrit Arunanondchai was talking a mile a minute recently about “with history in a room filled with people with funny names 4,” his video-and-sculpture show at Clearing, a gallery in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: ‘My Little Exploding Stars,’ Bridget Donahue Calls Her Artists
abstract: After just two years on the Bowery, a gallerist who struck out on her own has had one success after another.
lead_paragraph: Those seeking a primer on how to start a gallery could look to Bridget Donahue. Having opened on the Bowery just two years ago, she is — by any estimation — going gangbusters.

headline: Review: In ‘The Circle,’ Click Here if You Think You’re Being Watched
abstract: Emma Watson and Tom Hanks star in this adaptation of a Dave Eggers novel that explores surveillance-state threats.
lead_paragraph: From the drab 1995 cyberthriller “The Net” onward, mainstream American movies have been hard-pressed to pertinently weigh in on the internet and its discontents. Yes, comedies are regularly larded with “old folks can’t tweet” and “these darn kids and their ‘texting’” jokes, while espionage thrillers invariably serve up hot webcam action. But few pictures attempt to take a hard look at what it all means — perhaps because the entertainment business has some resentment about its digital usurpation.

headline: Where Art and Technology Collide
abstract: At the American Medium gallery, young artists are exploring the digital world with installations evoking cybertwee and the Post-Internet movement.
lead_paragraph: Galleries like American Medium that work with young artists — and cater to a crowd that has grown up with the internet — are approaching web-based art with a renewed purpose.

headline: 3 Books Tell the Legacies of Legends
abstract: A Shortlist that looks at major figures from our time and before.
lead_paragraph: MARGARET THATCHER A Life and Legacy By David Cannadine 162 pp. Oxford University, $14.95.

headline: Review: ‘Casting JonBenet’ Revisits a 1996 Murder
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In a conceptual exercise, actors audition for roles in the celebrated case as a way of showing how people are still preoccupied by it.
lead_paragraph: The conceit of the vacuous nonfiction movie “Casting JonBenet” is simple. Several dozen professional and nonprofessional actors audition onscreen for roles in the movie you’re watching, which is pegged to the 1996 murder of JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old beauty-pageant contestant from Boulder, Colo., who became a post-mortem media sensation. Her murder remains unsolved, which hasn’t stopped its exploitation. The director Kitty Green’s big idea here is to explore the tragedy and its aftershocks through the reactions of actors playing those involved in the case, including JonBenet’s parents. Some girls — smiling, dressed and made up as little beauty contestants — play JonBenet.

headline: New York Firefighters Say a Final Goodbye to a Brother in Blue
abstract: “He was a hard-core rocker and also a firefighter with a baby seat in the back of his minivan,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said of William N. Tolley, who died on duty last Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BETHPAGE, N.Y. — Firefighter William N. Tolley moved to the sounds of a rumble: the roar of his tower ladder rig and the growls of death metal, twin passions born in his teenage years and forged into night-and-day careers.

headline: Hunting Mushrooms, and What Makes Some Glow in the Dark
abstract: Scientists may have had more luck tracking down how some fungi glow than you may have hunting bioluminescent mushrooms, a reporter discovered.
lead_paragraph: PISGAH NATIONAL FOREST, N.C. — Here’s what I was told: Get away from the city, go during a new moon and keep my flashlight off. When the sky faded black enough to spot stars twinkling, I’d be able to see mushrooms glowing.

headline: A Restaurant Opens, a Tradition for Summer Interns Ends
abstract: At the recently opened Made Nice in Manhattan, four 20-somethings enjoy their last weekly lunch together as their internships come to a close.
lead_paragraph: On a recent overcast afternoon, the line to enter Made Nice, a new 31-seat fast-casual restaurant, snaked onto the sidewalk and down West 28th Street. After all, Daniel Humm and Will Guidara, of the lauded restaurants Eleven Madison Park and  NoMad, were attached. Inside the space, with its high ceilings, a Shepard Fairey mural and an open kitchen, some customers excitedly pored over paper menus and trawled for tables, while those lucky enough to be seated were tucking into their quinoa tabbouleh with falafel and pickled beets or khao salad with steak, crispy rice and roasted broccoli. The upbeat background music — a mix of hip-hop, ’90s hits and current tunes — added to the festive vibe. SHIVANI VORA

headline: Baby-Making by Lottery
abstract: Giving away costly reproductive treatments by the luck of the draw makes clear our Las Vegas-style culture of medicine, where you have to ante up for better care.
lead_paragraph: Dr. John Zhang, a well-known specialist in reproductive medicine who runs the New Hope Fertility Center out of a vast and science-fiction-looking office on Columbus Circle, believes he has played a singular role in the fiscal health of New York City. Patients come to him from around the world, from the Middle East, from Kenya, from Nigeria, Spain and China. Perhaps especially from China.

lead_paragraph: So here you are, in the thumping nucleus of the $45 billion global art market, home to 250 or more galleries of contemporary art. But why does the floor feel so unsteady?

headline: 6 Galleries to Visit Now in TriBeCa, SoHo and the West Village
abstract: In these neighborhood art galleries, bold text paintings, marijuana pipes made of blown glass and a rude marmoset.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Karp’s gallery OK Harris, which he opened in 1969, lasted on lower West Broadway until 2014, but by the end it was a stranger in a strange land, surrounded by fashion boutiques, watering holes and cigar stores. Pearl Paint, the beloved budget art supply depot, is gone, too.

headline: 10 Galleries to Visit Now on the Lower East Side
abstract: Political art, family portraits and abstract sculpture fill the land known as Loisaida, an area that has experienced extensive change.
lead_paragraph: New York City neighborhoods change; that’s life. And one that has changed drastically is the swath of real estate between 14th Street and Canal Street, east of the Bowery, known as the Lower East Side. Its northernmost section, the East Village, was psychedelia central in the 1960s, and in the early 1980s a hot, if short-lived, art gallery scene.

lead_paragraph: Anthony Levandowski, the Uber executive accused of stealing trade secrets from Google, is stepping aside from leading some of the company’s work on self-driving vehicles, amid a bare-knuckled legal fight between the two technology giants.

headline: Martha Lavey, a Leading Lady of Chicago Theater, Dies at 60
abstract: An actress by training, Ms. Lavey was artistic director of Steppenwolf Theater during a period of great expansion.
lead_paragraph: Martha Lavey, who took over as artistic director of the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago in 1995 and over the next 20 years made it a showcase for acclaimed productions and an incubator for new plays and young playwrights, died on Tuesday in Chicago. She was 60.

lead_paragraph: The upholstery guy. A cabinet builder. A drapery company. A hair-dye maker. A sprawling used-books/records/CD business.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tax Cuts for Everybody, and Responsibility for Nobody
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 28, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Trump’s plan basically is tax cuts for everyone. Real reform, with revenue neutrality, is difficult. There are winners and losers, but Trump apparently just wants winners.”

headline: 47 Galleries That Bring You the Art of Now
abstract: Here are some of our critics’ favorite gallery shows on view now. (But don’t expect a break from politics.)
lead_paragraph: In any given week, the art galleries of New York — and there are hundreds — are brimful of exhibitions showcasing works old and new, conventional and avant-garde, by the established and by the just discovered. This seems especially true right now, with the international art crowd set to jet into town for Frieze New York next weekend. Current shows feature repurposed pornography, depictions of the surveillance state, glass marijuana pipes, scrap metal, interpretations of a range of African-American experiences, prints from the land of Björk and a homage to the Duchamp urinal. There is magic, a little humor and no small amount of protest art.

headline: Fans Feel Robbed of Bill O’Reilly, but Stick With Fox
abstract: While many fans defended Mr. O’Reilly after his departure from Fox News, some network viewers said harassment accusations against him were worrisome.
lead_paragraph: Two days after Bill O’Reilly’s ouster from Fox News over sexual harassment accusations, Alyce Bradley sipped white wine at an outdoor mall in Alpharetta, Ga., and rued the loss of the network’s biggest star. She and her husband have watched Fox News for years — “It’s always on,” she said — and they enjoyed what they described as Mr. O’Reilly’s “biting commentary” and “different perspective.”

headline: Facing Tough Odds in French Vote, Le Pen Assails Macron
abstract: At a rally in Nice the far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen depicted her centrist opponent, Emmanuel Macron, as an unpatriotic out-of-touch banker.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — France’s far-right presidential candidate, Marine Le Pen, came out swinging against her centrist opponent, Emmanuel Macron, on Thursday night, depicting him as an unpatriotic out-of-touch banker in a tough, slashing speech intended to fuel her uphill bid for an upset in the May 7 runoff.

headline: At Jackie Robinson Museum, a Timeless Mission Will Live On
abstract: A groundbreaking took place for the museum, which founders hope will inspire a new generation to battle barriers. It is set to open in spring 2019.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Robinson will have a place, finally, to showcase her mother’s flowing white wedding gown. The pleated dress has been sitting in a dark closet in Connecticut for some 70 years, avoiding the ravages of age, and soon enough it will be on display at a new Jackie Robinson Museum in New York, near the Holland Tunnel.

headline: Cloud Produces Sunny Earnings at Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet
abstract: The impact on quarterly results announced Thursday was particularly acute at Amazon, far and away the leader in online computing services.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The moneymaking machines at the core of Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet, the parent company of Google, are notably different. But the respective kings of online retailing, software and internet search should all credit a relatively new line of business for lifting their financial results.

headline: Trump Orders Easing Safety Rules Implemented After Gulf Oil Spill
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: President Trump aims to roll back the Obama administration’s attempts to ban oil drilling off the southeastern Atlantic and Alaskan coasts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just past the seventh anniversary of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, President Trump on Friday directed the Interior Department to “reconsider” several safety regulations on offshore drilling implemented after one of the worst environmental disasters in the nation’s history.

headline: In Manchester, Calm Before a Stormy Summer
abstract: At some point, United and City, who drew, 0-0, on Thursday, will have to reflect on why a season that promised so much has delivered so little.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — This time, it felt more local, more intimate. The first Manchester derby of the season, in September, was a global event. The city had been declared the “capital of football,” home not only to two astonishingly wealthy, unapologetically ambitious clubs, but also to the two finest managers of their generation, two intractable foes. That first clash had the air of a game the world was watching.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Really Does Not Like Donald Trump
abstract: “This Fight Is Our Fight,” new on the hardcover nonfiction list, is nominally about the economy. But the index reveals a more personal target.
lead_paragraph: HER BACK PAGES: You can tell a lot about a book from its index. Consider Elizabeth Warren’s “This Fight Is Our Fight,” reviewed by Paul Krugman and new to the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1. On its face, the book — subtitled “The Battle to Save America’s Middle Class” — is all about economic issues, and the index is correspondingly flecked with terms like “layoffs” (one citation), “manufacturing decline” (one citation) and “rent assistance” (two citations). But really these are just the parsley on the meatloaf. Flip through the back pages and it’s clear that Warren, the hard-punching Massachusetts senator, has a more personal fight in mind: The index listing for “Trump, Donald” is divided into dozens of subcategories beginning with “bait-and-switch and” (two citations), then moving on to “bigotry and” (four citations), “corporate influences on” (five citations) and “trickle-down and” (seven citations). There are also listings for “tax returns and,” “‘nasty woman’ comment of” and — my favorite — “tweetstorms vs.,” which directs readers to a four-page recap of Warren’s social media battle with Trump during the presidential race. “I tweeted about how he cheated hardworking people who had built his hotels and golf courses,” she recalls. “I mentioned his bullying, his attacks on women, his racism, his obvious narcissism. And in that first tweetstorm, I did my best to sound the alarm: This guy is dangerous, and he could end up as president of the United States.”

headline: The ‘Quiet Moments’ of Waitresses at Work
abstract: The photographer Melissa Breyer found herself drawn to the stories playing out behind the windows of restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Breyer moved to New York to become a painter and ended up becoming a waitress, first at a pasta place in Greenwich Village, then at a bar and grill in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She enjoyed the social aspect of the work, but especially the quiet moments, when she could daydream “about the books I was reading or conversations I wanted to have or shoes I would like,” she said. “Things I wanted to do, places I wanted to go.” As she made the transition to photographer, writer and website editor, she found herself drawn to the stories playing out behind the windows of the restaurants she passed. The waitresses, especially, caught her attention. When they weren’t reciting the nightly specials or balancing dinner for four on one arm, what were they thinking? The photographs here, taken from either side of the restaurant window, ask this question without trying to answer it.

headline: 7 Key Themes in Rei Kawakubo’s Career
abstract: In advance of the Comme des Garçons designer's exhibition at the Costume Institute, Alexander Fury revisits important ideas in her work.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, the color black quickly became synonymous with Kawakubo’s aesthetic. When Comme des Garçons made its Paris Fashion Week debut in 1981, the clothes drew attention in their absolute absence of color — an impression that was underlined by interviews with Kawakubo, herself invariably dressed in blacks. Note the plural: Kawakubo used so much, it was possible to see shades and nuances of black in her collections. She wasn’t the first to design in black, of course — Chanel transformed it from a color of mourning into a color of fashion in the 1920s, with her little black dresses, and designers had used it ever since. But by the 1980s, it had fallen out of favor with the rising preference for flashier colors — the brilliant pinks and greens of Claude Montana and Thierry Mugler — and the greiges and navies of Giorgio Armani. Black had never been used with Kawakubo’s severity and insistence — she’s used the word “strength” to describe the color. But in 1988, Kawakubo seemed to abruptly change course: She showed a fall collection dominated by rich scarlet. The thought process behind the decision? “Red is black,” she said at the time. Kawakubo’s challenge to color — and perhaps, as the French theorist Jean Baudrillard reasoned, to the idea of women sporting loud hues being transformed into ‘objects’ — is one of the most important fashion statements of the late 20th century. It transformed black into a color of fashion, intellectualism and rebellion — women who wore her clothes were dubbed “the crows.” And when the Harvard School of Design gave Kawakubo an Excellence in Design Award in 2000, they stated that she “invented” black. Maybe not — but she did reinvent it.

abstract: The National Security Agency program was one of the most disputed forms of surveillance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency said Friday that it had halted one of the most disputed practices of its warrantless surveillance program, ending a once-secret form of wiretapping that dates to the Bush administration’s post-Sept. 11 expansion of national security powers.

headline: ‘10 Concerts’ Facebook Meme May Reveal More Than Musical Tastes
abstract: Privacy experts said the specific answers posted in response to the meme could be used by marketers to target ads or by hackers to breach secure accounts.
lead_paragraph: It’s all fun and games until someone’s password security question gets hacked.

headline: New Kosciuszko Bridge. Same Old Traffic.
abstract: It’s the first major new bridge built in New York City since 1964. The main traffic benefits may arrive in 2020, when a second crossing opens.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers gazed out at the towering new Kosciuszko Bridge as they prepared to drive across the shiny span for the first time on Friday morning. Then they cursed the traffic stretching endlessly before them.

headline: Daily Report: Cloud Computing Asserts Itself
abstract: Amazon Web Services has become the profit engine of the internet retailer. Can it stay ahead of rivals like Microsoft and Google?
lead_paragraph: It’s been said before but it bears repeating: If it were not for its cloud-computing business, Amazon.com would have difficulty reaching profitability.

headline: Trump’s Flip-Flops and the Dangers They Pose
abstract: A readers asks if we can survive “random choices on topics affecting millions of people, American society and even the viability of the planet.”

headline: On Long Island, Sessions Vows to Eradicate MS-13 Gang
abstract: Attorney General Jeff Sessions said the best way to get rid of the gang, which has ties to El Salvador, was to crack down on illegal immigration.
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — The attorney general of the United States, Jeff Sessions, came on Friday to this Long Island area besieged by the transnational gang known as MS-13, and in a 20-minute speech to local police commissioners and sheriffs vowed to eradicate the gang by cracking down on illegal immigration.

headline: Jim DeMint Is Said to Be Out at Heritage Foundation
abstract: The anticipated shake-up comes at an inopportune time for the group, with several major pieces of conservative legislation on the agenda in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Heritage Foundation, a powerful conservative think tank that played a significant role in shaping President Trump’s cabinet and tilting it far to the right, is expected to replace its leader, the former South Carolina senator and Tea Party leader Jim DeMint.

headline: A Stark Warning on Climate
abstract: “Weather events” serve as nature’s gentle warning of the cataclysm that awaits us, a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Court Gives Trump Small Victory in Push Against Clean Power Plan
abstract: An appeals court said it would delay a decision on the legality of the rule, which aims to tackle global warming by cutting emissions from coal-fired plants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal court said on Friday it would halt consideration of a major lawsuit over former President Barack Obama’s signature policy aimed at tackling global warming, handing the Trump administration a modest and perhaps temporary victory.

abstract: A lawyer whose specialty is workplace ethics notes improvement in reporting and resolution of whistle-blower reports.

headline: Their Asylum Requests Denied, Thousands Stay in Sweden (Some for Years)
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Out of 18,000 failed asylum seekers in the country, 12,500 have gone underground, according to the Swedish Border Police.
lead_paragraph: MALMO, Sweden — A family whose members say they fled Albania to escape a blood feud was rejected for asylum by Swedish officials, who months later asked them to leave.

headline: Our White House Reporters Recall Their Most Vivid Moments of Trump’s First 100 Days
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Covering the Trump White House can be exhilarating, maddening, exhausting — but never boring. The Times’ White House correspondents recall vivid moments from their first 100 days on the beat.
lead_paragraph: Covering the Trump White House can be exhilarating, maddening, exhausting — but never boring. The New York Times’s White House correspondents recall memorable moments from their first 100 days on the beat.

headline: ‘The Handmaid’s Tale,’ Season 1, Episode 2: Something Primal
abstract: Offred’s predicament grows more surreal.
lead_paragraph: After two episodes, “The Handmaid’s Tale” has shown that it excels at placing the horrific, the surreal and the achingly mundane side-by-side. In one image, four handmaids speak about the weather as dead bodies are strung up behind them, the only acknowledgment of their supposed crimes being the symbols on the bags that cloak their face. It’s a masterly composition, one which succeeds by the tensions of its juxtapositions. From the very beginning, it’s clear that this sort of garish imagery is meant to provoke us into wondering how such extremes are allowed to flourish.

headline: Last Chance: Jason Fox at Canada
abstract: At Canada gallery, politics is the theme of a series of portrait paintings of Barack Obama, Bob Marley, George Harrison and the artist’s dog.
lead_paragraph: A great American president, a mythic Rastafarian musician, a white dog named Duncan and a demonic being with the date of the day after the recent presidential election carved into its chest in scarlet — these are among the personages that combine and recombine throughout Jason Fox’s cycle of 23 raw portrait paintings at Canada. This excellent show is called “Square Cave,” which suggests that while we now live in rooms with corners, the Stone Age is not so far behind us, and could come again.

headline: A Whistle Was Blown, but Who Was Listening?
abstract: A former employee of Radian, the mortgage insurer, raised red flags and found himself in a lesser job; the S.E.C. has so far been mum.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission calls itself the whistle-blower’s advocate. But one participant in the agency’s lauded whistle-blower program isn’t so sure.

headline: Cell Research and Consent
abstract: A bioethicist says patient consent is nonnegotiable.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Playlist: Katy Perry and Haim Reach for New Flavors
keywords: ['Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Country Music']
abstract: Hear the week's most notable new songs, from a track off Willie Nelson's latest album to a bizarre song from Fall Out Boy.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

headline: Trump Nominates Former Disaster Relief Manager to Lead FEMA
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Brock Long, who once led the Alabama Emergency Management Agency, is currently working for an emergency management firm based in Illinois.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump nominated a former Alabama disaster relief manager on Friday to lead the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

headline: Light Noodles, Deep Flavor
abstract: Vietnamese rice noodle bowls are festooned with lemongrass-scented shrimp, a sweet-and-spicy sauce and piles of fresh herbs.
lead_paragraph: In Vietnam, the breakfast choice for many is a steaming bowl of brothy pho, purchased from early-morning vendors who dispense the beloved spicy noodle soup until their supply is sold out, then close up shop for the day.

headline: Congress at 100 Days: Frenetic Action but Few Accomplishments
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Partisanship and a chaotic White House have combined to undermine the opportunity for Republicans to enact the legislation they have long desired.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Owners of ancient water vessels are likely to be quite pleased with the Senate, which voted overwhelmingly this month to generally exempt them from a fire-retardant materials requirement. But that is about the extent of bipartisan legislation to emerge from Congress during the first 100 days of unified Republican governance.

headline: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 1, Episode 8: Bite the Bullet, Baby
abstract: Despite its many frustrating cliffhangers, the Season 1 finale was a powerhouse episode with deep psychological drama.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the new season of “Twin Peaks,” Noel Murray is helping to refresh our memory with a series of recaps covering the first two seasons. (It’s only been 26 years!) The new season debuts on May 21 on Showtime. Click here to read Noel’s recap of the feature-length pilot; here for Season 1, Episodes 2-7; and check back to Watching next week as he starts his rundown of  Season 2.

headline: 12 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
abstract: Tired of reading about the president’s first 100 days? Read about a disastrous “luxury” festival, the nature of genius and glow-in-the-dark fungi instead.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, we’re also tooting our own horn here. We’ll share can’t-miss Times articles from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

headline: N.F.L. Draft Round 2: Here Are the Best Available Players
abstract: A look at some of the best players still on the board, including Dalvin Cook, Cam Robinson, Kevin King and Quincy Wilson.
lead_paragraph: Think you can stop paying attention to the N.F.L. Draft? Think again. Among the star players who have recently been drafted in Round 2 are Le’Veon Bell, Janoris Jenkins, Alshon Jeffrey and Rob Gronkowski.

headline: It’s a Good Time to Trade Your Student Debt for Home Debt
abstract: Fannie Mae, the government-controlled mortgage corporation, is taking three steps to help ease student loan borrowers into homeownership.
lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae, the government-controlled mortgage giant, is taking steps to make it easier for millions of student loan borrowers to own a home or refinance a mortgage.

headline: Art Goes Political, but Will That Fly on the London Market?
abstract: Art with a political edge, or at least a heightened awareness of this moment, is starting to make an impact at commercial galleries in the British capital.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This will be remembered as a year when art got seriously political. The Whitney Biennial in New York and the inaugural Athens edition of Documenta are just two of the high-profile exhibitions trying to convey and confront the tumult of our times.

headline: Bringing Family Wealth to Bear Against a Relentless Illness
abstract: Family offices, which manage money for rich clans, sometimes throw their considerable weight behind efforts to tackle an illness afflicting one or more relatives.
lead_paragraph: Alice Anane’s father died suddenly of a brutal brain-wasting disease when he was 49. She was 15 at the time and remembers her family thinking that he had contracted mad cow disease on a trip to Britain.

headline: Review: ‘American Gods’ Works in Mysterious Ways
abstract: The new series, on Starz, is based on a 2001 novel from Neil Gaiman and finds a range of deities in a bloody and fractured narrative.
lead_paragraph: At one of the many tense moments in “American Gods,” a character named Shadow Moon pleads with his employer, Mr. Wednesday, saying, more or less: “I don’t give a fig if they don’t have a figging clue. I want one. Give me a figging clue.” This happens early in Episode 2, by which time viewers might want one, too.

headline: Chicago Aviation Security Chief Is Fired Weeks After United Episode
abstract: He supervised the officers who removed Dr. David Dao from a United flight, but his termination arose from an unrelated sexual harassment allegation.
lead_paragraph: Officers with the Chicago Department of Aviation at O’Hare International Airport provoked widespread outrage when they forcibly removed a passenger from his seat on a United Airlines flight. Now their supervisor has been fired, though not for a reason directly related to that case.

headline: China’s Environmental Woes, in Films That Go Viral, Then Vanish
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Environment']
abstract: Wang Jiuliang’s documentaries on topics like unregulated garbage dumps are internet sensations in China, but they are short-lived online.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Achieving fame was not hard for Wang Jiuliang, but staying in the spotlight has proved more difficult.

headline: Under the Trump Tax Plan, We Might All Want to Become Corporations
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Small Business', 'Corporations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Millions of Americans would have the chance to cut their taxes by essentially turning themselves into small business entities.
lead_paragraph: Corporations are people, Mitt Romney once told us. But if the Trump administration’s tax plan were to become law, in the future a whole lot of people may just become corporations.

headline: What Google and Twitter Say About Trump’s First 100 Days
abstract: The results of their data analyses aren’t all that shocking. It turns out the president posts a lot, and people searched Google for information on immigration.
lead_paragraph: The rulers of the social media and search worlds have run their high-powered analytics to give us incisive new insight into President Trump’s first 100 days in office.

headline: Climate of Complete Certainty
abstract: How about a reasonable conversation on what to do about our warming planet?
lead_paragraph: This is Bret Stephens’s first column.

headline: K.K.R. Finds an Activist at Its Gates
abstract: The investor ValueAct Capital has taken a stake in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Relations between the activist and the buyout firm are amicable, for now.
lead_paragraph: Some three decades after Henry Kravis was called a barbarian, he has encountered one at his own gate. Jeffrey W. Ubben, whose ValueAct Capital just disclosed an interest in Mr. Kravis’s buyout shop, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is usually friendlier in his approach with the companies in which he invests than the term might suggest. Even so, there is a chance things could get testy.

headline: Introducing Our New Columnist
abstract: As we continue to widen our range of views and enrich our debate, we welcome Bret Stephens to The Times Opinion pages.
lead_paragraph: I wanted to call your attention to our new columnist, Bret Stephens, whose first piece appears today. Bret, the winner of the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for commentary, has joined us from The Wall Street Journal, where he wrote the Global View column and also served as deputy editorial page editor.

headline: Vito Acconci, Performance Artist and Uncommon Architect, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Acconci made a radical career turn in the 1970s, when he abandoned the gallery world and remade himself as an architect.
lead_paragraph: Vito Acconci, a father of performance and video art and a shamanistic, poetic, deeply influential force on the New York art scene for decades, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: A Rainbow of Benefits
abstract: Galas were held recently for the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center; the A.S.P.C.A.; City Harvest; and PEN America.
lead_paragraph: City Harvest held its spring gala on April 25 at Cipriani 42nd Street. The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center honored Hillary Clinton and others at its awards dinner at Cipriani Wall Street on April 20. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals hosted a benefit at the Plaza Hotel on April 20. And the PEN Literary Gala took place on April 25 at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Heard of Giacomo Meyerbeer? He’s on the Cusp of a Musical Renaissance
abstract: A new album is one of the signs of renewed interest in the once-popular works of this 19th-century opera composer.
lead_paragraph: When the star soprano Diana Damrau joined the Virgin Classics label in 2006, she met its president, Alain Lanceron, after a performance. He asked what she’d like to record. A Mozart and Salieri collection, she answered — and an album of the once-celebrated, now-neglected 19th-century German opera composer Giacomo Meyerbeer.

headline: At Tate Galleries in London, Parting Gift Makes Waves: A Boat
abstract: The call for donations to buy a sailboat for the Tate group’s departing director angered employees and highlighted concern over widening inequality in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The practice of office workers pitching in to buy a gift for a departing colleague — especially one with decades of service — is an old tradition.

headline: Brazil Gripped by General Strike Over Austerity Measures
abstract: Tensions flared in Rio de Janeiro, with schools warning parents to keep students at home, security forces using tear gas and clashes erupting inside an airport.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A general strike disrupted cities around Brazil on Friday as unions marshaled resistance to austerity measures proposed by the scandal-ridden government of President Michel Temer, reflecting his struggle to persuade voters that his proposals to overhaul pension systems and labor laws are necessary.

headline: Laura Osnes, Star of Broadway’s ‘Bandstand,’ at Home
abstract: For the actress, a tiny walk-up offers an authentic New York experience.
lead_paragraph: The living room floor slopes in Laura Osnes’s fifth-floor walk-up on the Upper West Side, baffling Lyla, the resident Chihuahua, making guests question their alcohol intake and necessitating the removal of the rolling desk chair.

headline: Watch a Conversation With Roger Waters
abstract: Our chief pop music critic interviewed the musician ahead of his first studio album in 25 years, “Is This the Life We Really Want?”
lead_paragraph: Roger Waters, the songwriter behind Pink Floyd’s monumental concept albums and the master of the arena and stadium spectacle, is about to release his first studio album in 25 years, “Is This the Life We Really Want?”

headline: What I Love | Laura Osnes
abstract: A Broadway musical actress and her husband find happiness in a walk-up with a dog and a deck.
lead_paragraph: A Broadway musical actress and her husband find happiness in a walk-up with a dog and a deck.

headline: Creative Marketing for Luxury Condos
abstract: With a glut of inventory in high-end real estate, brokers have been hosting some unusual events to attract attention.
lead_paragraph: After a burst of construction, the luxury real estate market is awash with million- and multimillion-dollar homes for sale. Buyers are taking their time before signing on the dotted line, and sales agents and brokers have had to get more creative in drawing attention to their listings.

headline: Review: An Old Stravinsky ‘Funeral Song’ Rumbles Anew
abstract: The New York Philharmonic gave the New York “premiere” of the piece, written in 1908 and long believed lost.
lead_paragraph: Stravinsky’s long-lost “Funeral Song,” which he wrote as a 26-year-old in 1908 in memory of his teacher, Rimsky-Korsakov, was rediscovered just two years ago by Russian musicologists. Since its “premiere” in December, it has been making the rounds of world orchestras and arrived at the New York Philharmonic on Thursday.

headline: ‘Trump Bump’ Lifts Stocks, Giving President a Win for His First 100 Days
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is up about 5 percent since Mr. Trump’s inauguration, the best start for a president since the elder George Bush.
lead_paragraph: In his first 100 days as president, Donald J. Trump may have found much of his agenda stymied, like a health care overhaul and a hotly contested immigration order.

headline: Drug Evidence Will Be Permitted at Cosby Trial
abstract: A judge ruled that prosecutors may present evidence at Bill Cosby’s trial that he procured quaaludes to give to women in pursuit of sex.
lead_paragraph: Despite a challenge by Bill Cosby’s lawyers, prosecutors in his criminal trial will be able to present evidence that he obtained quaaludes to help him in his pursuit of sex with women, a judge ruled Friday.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web from our staffers, including Carolyn Ryan, Rod Nordland and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Luxury Rentals Use Apps to Pique Interest
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mobile Applications', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: With a smartphone swipe, tenants of high-end buildings can pay the rent, reserve a common area for a barbecue or alert the super to a broken appliance.
lead_paragraph: When Nicole Silver wants to book a yoga class in her new apartment building or notify the doorman that her cousin is staying over while she jets off to Thailand, she does not make a phone call, send an email, or leave a note.

headline: Review: Eugenio Derbez as Just a Gigolo in ‘How to Be a Latin Lover’
abstract: In this good-natured comedy, the Mexican actor and comedian has been dumped and has to settle for real life.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican actor and comedian Eugenio Derbez is a superstar in his own country and in Hispanic communities in the United States, but he is virtually unknown to non-Hispanic viewers. (He has been seen, in small roles, in the likes of “Beverly Hills Chihuahua” and Adam Sandler’s “Jack and Jill,” neither exactly a star-making vehicle.) “How to Be a Latin Lover,” which bids to introduce him to a wider audience in the United States, is surprisingly deft in mixing Mr. Derbez’s broad but accomplished style with more ostensibly hip-absurdist Anglo modes of humor. Body-function jokes are, of course, a universal comedic language, and they’re here, too, although not as abundant as you might have expected.

headline: Review: Abdullah Ibrahim Revisits the Past at Town Hall
abstract: Mr. Ibrahim performed with his band Ekaya, and revived the repertoire of his first band, the Jazz Epistles.
lead_paragraph: Since leaving South Africa in the early 1960s to escape apartheid and pursue an international career, the jazz pianist Abdullah Ibrahim has made music with a sense of tenuous suspension. You could say his is a gospel of near-deliverance.

headline: 5 Sublime Minutes by a Maverick: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
abstract: Music by the pioneer Lou Harrison, Anna Netrebko at the Met Opera and a class with the organist Paul Jacobs were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what they’ve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

headline: Tired of Mother’s Day Brunch? Try a Tea
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Tea', "Mother's Day", 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Giraffes']
abstract: A number of hotels in the United States are charting a new course for the holiday: a variety of teas, sandwiches and chocolate.
lead_paragraph: Instead of celebrating Mother’s Day, on May 14, with the usual brunch, why not go for tea instead? Several hotels in the United States are hosting teas for the occasion, many of which are substantial enough to qualify as meals and more creative than the traditional scone and finger sandwich affairs; they are also open to both hotel guests and nonguests.

headline: New York City Ballet: A Story in Three Choreographers
abstract: The company’s Here/Now Festival begins with programs focusing on the work of Christopher Wheeldon, Alexei Ratmansky and Justin Peck.
lead_paragraph: By the numbers alone, New York City Ballet’s Here/Now Festival is mind-blowing. Over the course of four weeks, the company is dancing 43 ballets by 22 choreographers. Even if that accounts for less than a quarter of the 230 works that more than 60 choreographers have made for the troupe since the death of its godlike founding choreographer, George Balanchine, in 1983, it’s still an epic-size sample. No other ballet company in the world can approach these numbers.

headline: Trump Orders Review of Safety Rules Created After Gulf Oil Spill
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: President Trump aims to roll back the Obama administration’s attempts to ban oil drilling off the southeastern Atlantic and Alaskan coasts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days after the seventh anniversary of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, one of the worst environmental disasters in the nation’s history, President Trump on Friday directed the Interior Department to “reconsider” several safety regulations on offshore drilling put in place after the spill.

headline: A Hospital No Longer Afloat, but Buoyant With Memories
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Relocation of Business', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: An exhibit of documents and photos from the Floating Hospital is on display in Long Island City.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Delgado, an aspiring archivist from Queens College, has been telling friends that he went through yellowing documents and old photographs for an exhibit showcasing the history of the Floating Hospital. They all asked the same question: “Is it still on a boat?”

headline: If Mars Is Colonized, We May Not Need to Ship In the Bricks
abstract: A new study suggests the material humanity needs to one day construct structures on Mars may already exist within the red planet’s desolate soil.
lead_paragraph: We often wonder if somewhere hidden on Mars are the building blocks for life. But what about building blocks for a civilization?

headline: Let’s Talk About Australia
abstract: The New York Times is expanding its coverage of Australia and the region and we’re inviting subscribers to help us shape the project with questions and discussion.

headline: The Sunny Escapism of the Photographer Gray Malin
abstract: His pictures of balloons, life preservers and llamas are meant to soothe rather than provoke, and Rihanna and Reese Witherspoon are among his fans.
lead_paragraph: “Honey, doesn’t this look just like a Gray Malin photograph?”

headline: Tennis, for Anyone? In the Bronx, the Answer Is Yes
abstract: At Crotona Park, a stylish new clubhouse is about more than topspin. It’s the home of a tennis and tutoring program for underserved children.
lead_paragraph: One of the city’s best new works of public architecture sounds like a perk for the country club set. And it is. Partly. Tucked into Crotona Park in the Bronx, the Cary Leeds Center for Tennis & Learning is anchored by a modest two-story concrete-and-steel clubhouse, all sleek surfaces and sharp angles, overlooking a competition-worthy pair of exhibition courts.

headline: On ‘Gotham,’ Ben McKenzie Goes From Detective to Director
abstract: Mr. McKenzie, who plays James Gordon, talks about his noir city filled with villains and what it was like to direct the show.
lead_paragraph: On a cold night in January, in a dark alley off Great Jones Street in Manhattan, Bruce Wayne was getting ready to fly.

headline: Florence Finch, Unsung War Hero Who Took On Japanese, Dies at 101
abstract: During World War II, Mrs. Finch quietly undermined Japan when it occupied the Philippines, and was tortured for it. Then she quietly raised a family in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Florence Finch was an atypical hometown hero. For nearly 50 years after World War II, virtually no one outside of her family knew that she was a highly decorated Coast Guard veteran and a former prisoner of war whose exploits had been buried in time.

headline: Trump Could Save Tens of Millions of Dollars in One Year Under His Proposed Tax Plan
abstract: Mr. Trump would benefit from his proposed repeal of the Alternative Minimum Tax and a reduction in other tax rates.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump would benefit from his proposed repeal of the Alternative Minimum Tax and a reduction in other tax rates.

lead_paragraph: Each week, Canada Today mixes The New York Times’s recent Canada-related coverage with back stories and analysis from our reporters, along with opinions from our readers.

headline: Penn Station Work Will Cause 2 to 3 Major Weekday Disruptions, Amtrak Says
abstract: Amtrak’s chief executive could not say exactly when the disruptions would occur or how long they would last, only that “it’s certainly not going to be every day this summer.”
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Amtrak officials said on Friday that overhauling the tracks and rail equipment at Pennsylvania Station in New York would require two or three significant disruptions to commuting schedules over the summer.

headline: February’s Book Club Pick: ‘Killers of the Flower Moon,’ by David Grann
abstract: A shattering history of oil greed, racism and serial murder targeting the Osage Indians is uncovered.
lead_paragraph: KILLERS OF THE FLOWER MOON The Osage Murders and the Birth of the F.B.I. By David Grann 338 pp. Doubleday. $28.95.

headline: Judging Love at the ‘Seinfeld’ Diner
abstract: Inside the process of choosing a winner for the Modern Love college essay contest, which received nearly 2,000 submissions.
lead_paragraph: We were three people facing nearly 2,000 student essays about love. In early February, we in Sunday Styles had kicked off our fourth Modern Love college essay contest, asking undergraduates nationwide to write about what love was like for them, triggering an outpouring of heartbreak and soul-searching the likes of which we had never seen (well, except for two years before, when we last held the contest).

headline: A New North Korean Missile Test Ends in Failure
abstract: It was the North’s first test since it launched a ballistic missile near its submarine base on North Korea’s east coast on April 16. That launch was also a failure.

lead_paragraph: JOAL, Senegal — Once upon a time, the seas teemed with mackerel, squid and sardines, and life was good. But now, on opposite sides of the globe, sun-creased fishermen lament as they reel in their nearly empty nets.

lead_paragraph: When the comedian Hasan Minhaj stepped up to deliver his remarks at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner on Saturday night, he had known for more than two months that President Trump would skip  the gala. Samantha Bee, who broadcast her own competing event, called the “Not the White House Correspondents’ Dinner,” on the same night, probably never wanted Mr. Trump there in the first place.

headline: Young, Idealistic but Determined, Slovaks Lead Anticorruption Crusade
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: With anti-authoritarian protests erupting across Eastern Europe, a pair of teenagers are among the young people taking action.
lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — The pair of budding corruption fighters paused outside Slovakia’s presidential palace, trying to decide how long to give the government to capitulate to their demands. They wanted the resignations of the interior minister and the national police chief, as well as full and transparent investigations of a parade of recent corruption scandals. And that was just a start — the demonstration they had organized on Facebook was only a few hours away.

abstract: The president’s threat to pull the United States out of the North American Free Trade Agreement would hurt the very workers he says he aims to help.
lead_paragraph: As political theater, the threat last week from the Trump administration that it would pull the United States out of the North American Free Trade Agreement effectively enhanced the White House story line. From the campaign through his first 100 days in office, President Trump adroitly exploited the most conspicuous downsides of trade in portraying himself as a hero to those who go to work in coveralls.

headline: Understanding What Makes Plants Happy
abstract: Thomas Rainer’s work is a revelation: It turns out that plants are social, and have a body language that explains what they need.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Rainer and I have both been doing the botanical thing for decades; we know, and use, many of the same plants — and even much of the same horticultural vocabulary. But what he and I see when we look at a butterfly weed or a coneflower, or what we mean when we say familiar words like “layering” or “ground cover,” is surprisingly not synonymous.

The decisions jolted the global, 13-million-member church, which is intensely divided over gay marriage and gay clergy.

headline: In NoLIta, a Tribute to Forgotten History

He’s being literal.

headline: The Power and the Questioned Glory of Baseball’s Save Stat
abstract: Closers are the swaggering stars of many a bullpen. They are measured and rewarded by a statistic that may be overrated or mysteriously appropriate.
lead_paragraph: Addison Reed is the Mets’ setup man, the reliever who pitches the penultimate inning of the game based on the modern construction of baseball bullpens. All innings count the same, yet closers, who handle the game’s final inning, get much of the fame and the financial rewards that come with it.

headline: Where Totem Poles Are a Living Art (and Relics Rest in Peace)
abstract: Inspired by ancestral works, including one stored in a shed, a master carver pays tribute to a practice once common in the Haida Gwaii islands of Canada.
lead_paragraph: Imagine opening an old shed by the side of the road and finding a 19th-century painting by a master artist. That’s what happened to me recently in the small, indigenous village of Old Massett — except the ancient art was a totem pole, and a master carver, Christian White, led me there.

headline: Review: ‘The Dreyfus Affair’ and the Sound of Anxiety

headline: Chelsea Cruises, and It’s All Over but the Critiquing
abstract: Chelsea under Antonio Conte is ruthless and it is clinical, and that is why it will almost surely be the Premier League champion.

lead_paragraph: The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth prides itself on its collection of works by modern masters like Picasso, Matisse and Mondrian. And now it can add Amedeo Modigliani, the Italian artist who died young and today fetches upward of $170 million at auctions, to its roster.

headline: Apple’s Stock Races Ahead as Investors Bet on New iPhones

Apple’s once-unstoppable growth had come to a crashing halt: The number of iPhones sold was down 13 percent, and the company posted its first revenue decline in 13 years.

headline: Ueli Steck, Renowned Mountain Climber, Dies Near Everest at 40
abstract: Mr. Steck was preparing to traverse some of the Himalayas’ highest peaks when he died in an accident, though the exact circumstances of the death were unknown.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Ueli Steck, a renowned mountain climber nicknamed “the Swiss Machine” for his rapid ascents of some of the world’s most imposing peaks, died in an accident on Sunday at a camp near Mount Everest, Nepali officials said.

headline: Lights, Camera, Obits!
abstract: The reporter William Grimes talks about his onscreen appearance in “Obits,” a new documentary about a department reveling in newfound glamour.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the New York Public Library played host to a panel discussion called “Dead From the NYPL: The Perverse Pleasures of Obituaries.” It drew an overflow, enthralled crowd, of which I was a member. As the evening wore on, it occurred to me for the first time that the writing of obituaries — my job at The Times since 2008 — might be a glamorous occupation with an enthusiastic fan base.

headline: Review: Stravinsky’s ‘Rite’ as a Piano Duo Captivates Carnegie Hall
abstract: Leif Ove Andsnes and Marc-André Hamelin gave a commanding performance and received a long standing ovation.
lead_paragraph: Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” retains the power to shock in part through its raw, blazingly colorful orchestration. But the piece actually first came into being as a piano duo. Throughout his life, Stravinsky liked to sketch his pieces at the piano. So the piano version of the “Rite” is, in a way, the original.

headline: Review: A Souped-Up ‘Dreamgirls’ Roars in London
abstract: Amber Riley owns center stage without even seeming to try in Casey Nicholaw’s high-octane revival of this Supremes-inspired musical.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Effie White says that she’s nobody’s backup singer, it’s obvious she’s just speaking the simple truth. Never mind that when she makes this pronouncement, with a certainty that is as natural to her as breathing, it’s still early in Casey Nicholaw’s supercharged revival of “Dreamgirls,” a popular hit at the Savoy Theater here.

headline: Cuomo Has the Opportunity to Fix Penn Station, but Will He?
abstract: The transportation hub serving about 650,000 daily passengers desperately needs an overhaul. So far, the New York governor’s plans don’t begin to address the problems.
lead_paragraph: Almost every administration has a telltale moment. For Chris Christie, the New Jersey governor, it may well have come in 2010, before Bridgegate, when he stopped a plan to build new passenger rail tunnels under the Hudson River, connecting to Pennsylvania Station, claiming they cost New Jersey residents too dearly. In that one decision, he seemed to prove what critics would later say: He put shortsighted politics before constituents, and himself above public welfare.

headline: ‘Encyclopedic’ Brooklyn Museum Vies for Contemporary Attention
abstract: The myriad challenges for Anne Pasternak, director of this institution, include remaining true to Brooklyn’s identity while embracing a shift in trends.

headline: Singing With, but Not Through, the Nose
abstract: For Cyrano — a challenging role even without foam prosthetics on your face — the tenor Roberto Alagna said he tried hard to focus his sound.
lead_paragraph: Filling the giant Metropolitan Opera House with ringing high notes and without microphones is hard. Doing it with a big piece of foam glued to the end of your nose is even tougher — especially if you don’t want your tone to conjure thoughts of clothespins or head colds.

headline: Passion and Politics in João Bosco’s Brazilian Rhythms
abstract: Mr. Bosco, who practices relentlessly, helped empower Brazilians living under dictatorship in the 1970s and early ’80s with songs of pride and fighting spirit.
lead_paragraph: Two centuries of his country’s rhythms flow through the fingers of João Bosco, one of Brazil’s most fabled guitarists, singers and composers. Now 70, he can stir up a whirlwind of speed and agility, breezing through tricky meters, harmonies and beats from all over Brazil.

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Kate Moore’s ‘The Radium Girls’
keywords: ['Radiation', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The stories of a group of company workers whose exposure to a seemingly magical luminescent paint became deadly.
lead_paragraph: In the early 20th century, the United States Radium Corporation hired young women to paint the numbers and hands on watches so they could be seen in the dark. By the end of a day’s work, the women glowed, too. The seemingly magical substance in the paint that covered them — and gave them the name “shining girls” — was, of course, highly radioactive. The resulting tragic deaths led, eventually, to several of the women suing the company, in what would become a landmark workers’ rights case. In “The Radium Girls,” Kate Moore tells the story of these women, from their initial excitement about the work to their realization that it was killing them to their legal battles. Below, Ms. Moore tells us about the inspiration for the book, what surprised her most while researching it and more.

One route touches five states, skirting bigger cities and cutting through smaller ones, but mostly the journey is spent cruising along on six-lane highways, whipping past a blur of trees.

lead_paragraph: Why didn’t defenseman Brendan Smith see more ice time in the third period? Why wasn’t the checking line out there in overtime? Why, oh why, do the Rangers keep throwing away almost certain victories in the final minutes of playoff games?
